![[https://www.linkedin.com/posts/saifedean_diabolically-billions-of-people-worldwide-activity-7237835720420130816-7x5l?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/saifedean_diabolically-billions-of-people-worldwide-activity-7237835720420130816-7x5l?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop)](https://miro.medium.com/1*gj7TJkRJlFCkY2DJMg6B6w.png)

I strongly believe that money doesn't need to lose value to drive productivity. While I fundamentally disagree with Askar's viewpoint, I appreciate hearing perspectives that serve as a reminder of two key things: A) We are still early in this Bitcoin journey. B) The influence of fiat-based thinking is deeply ingrained, especially given that most colleges teach Keynesian Economics. It's surprising that some still believe money must depreciate to fuel productivity, but this only underscores the importance of continuing this discussion.

That said, it's Friday, and the Eagles are playing, so I'm off to enjoy some sports ball at a bar with my friends :)

9/6/24

Conor Jay Chepenik
